I agree with Jenny. Some places find it perfectly normal to eat cats and 
dogs. Heck, in the Philippines they eat horse too. And here in the west we 
find it horrible. It's just like how other cultures/religions think eating

It's weird. I know. xD
comments.author: LOneSTarX13

comments.text:
It's not a stereotype it's true. If you go to any Asian country Beef is 
excessively expensive (Plus Ox's are used for farming, why kill your lively 
hood?). I have family in Vietnam, and they have dog and cats restaurants. 
Their mind set really is that dogs are used as guard dogs and if they are 
incapable of protecting the family, then I might as well feed the family. 
That's what I can say for modern days, but I'm sure it was an issue of 
scarcity and famine (last resort kinds of things).

It's a European standard, barbaric is actually a stereotype created by the 
Romans. When they were expanding they didn't understand what the people 
where saying all they heard was "bar bar bar" = Barbaric. You can also spin 
it like kids today with Asian cultures, "Ching Chong Ching".   

You eat what you have. And what you can afford.
comments.author: Jenny Dam

top_comment.text:
So.. I'm going to school so I'm actually able to go over to S. Korea and 
teach. Problem is, I have a Double Yellow Headed Amazon and don't know if 
they'll allow me to bring him with me. He has all of his legal papers, as 
well as the little metal bracelet thingy around his leg (IDK what it's 
called). It's really a concern for me though. I really want to go to Korea, 
but I can't just get rid of my bird, he'd die. My mom chose him when he was 
an egg and once he was old enough began to raise him, and then I was born a 
year later. I plan on keeping him the rest of my life (They live 80+ years) 
He knows our names, and he hates being alone with strangers (he starts to 
pull his feathers because of the depression). I know somebody would say 
something like "Why not just leave him with your mom?" or something of that 
sort, But that's another problem. She 72 AND has stage four breast cancer. 
But thats a completely different story. I guess what I'm trying to get 
around to asking is if I'm able to bring a parrot into S. Korea? I've 
looked at a BUNCH of sites but none of them are giving me clear answers 
>_< ﻿
top_comment.author: Rebecca Marie

comments.text:
Thank you.. ^^ I am just really concerned because this is something I'm 
going to school for, but I can't leave something so precious to me behind 
either. ~_~
comments.author: Rebecca Marie

top_comment.text:
With the conversations about pet mills. Here in Ohio, US there's a pet shop 
called PetLand that claims to be rescuing dogs and cats and how they care 
about their animals when in reality, they're getting their animals from 
amish pet mills.
I went there once and a little girl on her way out asked me to take the 
kitten she was holding so I did. This kitten could not have been older than 
4 weeks. It could hardly stand and it was OBVIOUSLY malnourished and 
unwell. NEVER NEVER NEVER take cats or dogs away from their mothers before 
8 weeks!!! They learn so much from their families that it's worth it to 
wait! They were also asking for $900 for this tiny, ill kitten that they 
claimed was pure Russian Blue (it wasnt [yellow eyes]) and when I told them 
I wasnt going to buy it, the clerk offered to let me set up a monthly 
payment plan for it. That means theyre desperate to get animals out of the 
store enough to knowingly give a living creature to a family that probably 
cant afford living costs for said animal. Not to mention the horrendous vet 
bills.
I really wish people were more educated about these types of places. ﻿
top_comment.author: Anatolie

comments.text: That is so sad. Why do people do this to innocent animals...... ;_:
comments.author: Lydia LeClaire

comments.text:
I'm from Ohio as well, I've had amish people as neighbors, but I've never 
seen them run pet mills. :( That's so sad..

does spudgy and memers understand korean when you speak to them or do you

top_comment.author: kyoxtohru112

comments.text:
+Hannah I've always trained my own dogs and cats.  Intonation is important 
but you can't just switch out a word for another word and expect the same 
result.  I can't say "cheese" and expect my dog or cat to know I want them 
to "lay".  Maybe I can get away with "may" instead of "lay" but the sounds 
have to be similar.  You don't want to confuse your pet, you'll always get 
the best results if you consistently use the same words for the same 
actions.  Also, hand gestures are very useful as well.  I use gestures 
along with commands, especially when it comes to them getting a treat for 
something.  Their eyes are on my hand and the treat, so if I turn my hand 
away, they know they are not getting the treat yet.  If I turn it towards 
them, they know I'm offering them the treat now.  Some dogs are better at 
this than others but this method has always worked very well with my dogs 
and cats.
comments.author: Elizabeth Booth

comments.text:
What I've noticed from watching their videos is that they speak to them in 
both languages, and the animals 'understand' both, but really the only 
thing that an animal listens to is the intonation of voice. You could be 
saying anything, but if you say it with the same intonation that you 
normally use to command "come here" then they will respond and come to you.
comments.author: Girl, International

captions.text: Asa Ae asks:
Hey!
Isn’t it about time you guys talk about having pets in Korea?
It does seem like it’s that time.
You know what, I think that this is about the perfect time
To do so
According to my watch,
Which is covered in animals, and dogs,
Mine is covered in Lego pieces
Mine is covered in some kind of octopus.
Alright lets get something off our chests before we
Start talking about this one.
Hey commenters,
I know that you’re probably going to say this
But don’t worry about it,
If you’re going to bring your dog to Korea,
Don’t get this idea that Korean people walk around
With forks and knives and just
Stab random dogs and eat them
That does NOT happen.
Did you know that Canadians eat moose?
That is disgusting
I don’t know if we do eat moose actually.
I think there might be a moose meat shop
You know how you pluralize moose?
Mice?
Meese.
So we’ve been here for five years now
And in the past five years we have noticed
Quite a bit of a change in the attitudes towards
Pets in Korea.
Yeah, I know that when we first got Spudgy
Five years ago,
There were really almost no dogs in our neighborhood.
Right.
When we took him for a walk,
A lot of people were really afraid of him.
Its like they didn’t see a lot of dogs.
But by the time we left Bucheon,
Four years later,
There were like, impromptu dog parties,
At the park near our house.
Yeah! We did a video of a day in the life
Of us back in Bucheon, and you actually saw us
At one of these dog parties in the Bucheon park.
With lots of different breeds,
And we would meet dogs on like every corner.
So I feel like there’s been an increase in
Pet ownership in Korea in like the last five years.
It is a hip thing to do.
You should own a dog.
What we have noticed, however,
That hasn’t really changed,
Is that people still seem to be
A little bit afraid of cats.
Yeah, maybe the whole cat thing hasn’t really hit,
It’s hit Japan alright.
But, not Korea.
We even had a local coffee shop in Bucheon where
People had two cats walking around at Twelveda
Hi we miss you!
Some people would go in
and the girls would like FREAK,
Freeze in terror!
I mean they would be like,
AHHHHHHHHHHHHH
And I mean like, it’s a cat
In a café.
Do you think this cat would like a feral cat
That’s gonna like hunt you down in the wilderness?
Like if I was in the Savannah I would scream like a girl.
I’ll tell you one thing.
I know that back when I was in Canada
I was like the Ace Ventura of stray cats.
I could be like
“COME TO ME, MY ANIMALS”
And they would come up and purr and be friendly
In Korea I have not met
ONE
FRIENDLY
STRAY CAT
WHATSOEVER.
The point is that I don’t think people
Are as comfortable with pet cats yet.
Lets talk about pet stuff.
So, if you bring your pet to Korea,
What are you going to see pet-wise in Korea?
Well, within the past five years
We’ve also seen an increase of pet stores.
Sprouting up everywhere.
I mean really, I feel like there’s a pet store
On every corner now.
Except the thing is
These pet stores are really small shops.
I haven’t actually seen any
Ginormous kind of
Wal-Mart-sized pets’ mart.
You know where they have
Aisles dedicated to just like
Iguana colostomy bags and what not
What the?!
There’s the iguana colostomy bag section at Pet ‘smart!
Look, I’m not making this up.
He’s definitely making this up.
Now I know that Korea doesn’t have the land for making
These-sized Pet ‘smart giant stores,
So all these little tiny pet shops
I’ve noticed
Pretty much sell the exact same thing over and over again.
Yeah.
So it’s not like you go to all these different pet stores
And this one has like, organic
And this one has something for you pet
I was going to say pet chicken.
I don’t know why that came into my mind.
Pet hamster.
We have a friend whose cat’s name is Chicken.
Its true, the name is Chicken.
I wouldn’t say they stock the same things
I complain because, Spudgy
You might think is a small dog,
But he’s actually not a small dog in Korea.
Right. The pet stores will all have like,
Small,
“Medium”-sized clothing
or harnesses or crates,
but they don’t fit Spudgy, so.
Spudgy’s too big.
A lot of the dogs we find here,
Most of the time are just small toy dogs.
A lot of Yorkies here.
Yorkies, Maltese, Pekinese, Shi Tzu.
We rarely see giant dogs here.
I really want to see a big dog in Korea
It’s not really popular. No.
Not yet.
We’ve seen like a German shepherd
Here and there
But that really horrifies people.
There are some bulldogs running around.
They have some dire wolves as well.
Yeah. That’s right a couple of those.
That’s why I think
A lot of small, very small-medium kind of clothing
And stuff so
If you do have a big dog and you’re coming to Korea
You’re going to have to bring all that stuff with you
Including big size bones—
Hold on. People actually put sweaters on giant dogs?
Yes.
People have different
Pet-sized bowls, pet sized stands, pet sized bones,
You can’t get any of that in Korea for a big dog.
I haven’t seen any giant bones for dogs.
Or crates.
So if you’re travelling back and forth,
